guest.name: Bob Baxley
guest.title: Designer, Executive, Advisor
guest.background: Design leader who played a pivotal role in the Apple Online Store, App Store, Pinterest, and Yahoo Answers. Known for applying 'Silicon Valley' design thinking to enterprise software and advocating for design as a moral obligation.

episodeSummary: Bob Baxley discusses the evolution of design, arguing that software is a powerful medium akin to film or music that carries a moral obligation to respect user emotion. He challenges standard startup wisdom by advocating for design to report to engineering, delaying high-fidelity prototyping to avoid the 'Primal Mark' bias, and replacing generic design principles with opinionated 'Tenets' that drive hard decision-making.

methodologies.name: The Decision-Driving Tenets Framework
methodologies.summary: A framework for replacing generic, non-controversial 'principles' (like 'simple' or 'fast') with opinionated 'tenets' that force specific trade-offs. This method converts recurring organizational debates into permanent, binary decisions to speed up future execution.
principles: Identify recurring debates where teams get stuck
Make a definitive, opinionated choice (A over B)
Codify the choice as a Tenet to prevent re-litigating
methodologies.problemItSolves: Eliminates circular debates and ambiguity caused by 'Applehood & Motherpie' principles that no one disagrees with but help no one decide.
methodologies.whenToUse: When teams are constantly re-litigating the same trade-offs (e.g., Flexibility vs. Simplicity) or when a product lacks a distinct point of view.
methodologies.commonMistakes: Creating 'Principles' that are universally true (e.g., 'Make it easy to use') rather than 'Tenets' which take a side (e.g., 'Documentation is a failure state').
methodologies.quote: Principles are not useful as decision-making tools because nobody would ever argue the opposite... Tenets are really decision-making tools.
methodologies.realWorldExample: ThoughtSpot's Tenets: 1. Documentation is a failure state. 2. Start simple, user opts-in to complexity. 3. Look and feel like a single mind.

visualizationData.title: From Debate to Tenet
steps: Observe Recurring Friction: Identify where the team constantly argues (e.g., Power vs. Simplicity).
Force a Binary Choice: Decide essentially 'We are a paper person, not a plastic person'â€”pick a side.
Codify as Tenet: Write it as a rule (e.g., 'Opt-in to Complexity') to stop future debate.
Choreograph Execution: Use the Tenet as a constraint for all future design/eng decisions.

methodologies.name: The 'Primal Mark' Protocol
methodologies.summary: A protocol to delay high-fidelity visualization as long as possible. Based on the artistic concept that the first mark on a canvas (the Primal Mark) biases all subsequent decisions. By staying in 'low fidelity' (words/blocks) longer, teams can explore more creative directions before getting locked into a specific visual implementation.
principles: Wait as long as possible to draw a realistic picture
Use words (scripts) to define the problem first
Use 'Block Brain Diagrams' (conceptual layouts) before UI
Computers do not tolerate ambiguity; resolve it before coding
methodologies.problemItSolves: Prevents teams from anchoring on the first visual idea (especially dangerous with GenAI prototyping) and mistaking high-fidelity polish for a solved problem.
methodologies.whenToUse: During the early stages of feature development or new product innovation when the core concept is still fragile.
methodologies.commonMistakes: Jumping straight to Figma or AI prototyping tools to 'see what it looks like,' which shuts down conceptual divergent thinking.
methodologies.quote: As soon as you draw a picture that looks even remotely real, everybody gravitated towards that and said, 'oh, that's the thing.'
methodologies.realWorldExample: At ThoughtSpot, the team used 'Block Brain Diagrams' for weeks to align on logic. Once locked, the high-res UI was generated by an agency in a single day.

phases.name: Phase 1: The Script
phases.description: Text-based definition. Removing ambiguity through words/PRDs. No visuals allowed.

phases.name: Phase 2: The Storyboard
phases.description: Block Brain Diagrams. Low-fidelity structural layout. Focus on concept and flow, not pixels.

phases.name: Phase 3: Production
phases.description: High-Fidelity UI/Code. Rapid execution of the agreed concept. The 'Primal Mark' is finally made.

methodologies.name: The 'Software as a Medium' Model
methodologies.summary: A mental model that redefines software not as a utility, but as a media format (like film or music) capable of eliciting emotion. This model posits that builders have a moral obligation to manage the emotional energy users expend while interacting with the product.
principles: Software is an anonymous medium connecting maker to user
Every interaction extracts or deposits emotional energy
Makers must intend a specific emotional response
Focus on the 'grandmother in Ohio' using your tool
methodologies.problemItSolves: Transforms transactional, frustrating products into emotionally resonant experiences by shifting the maker's mindset from 'utility' to 'human connection'.
methodologies.whenToUse: When setting product vision or when a team becomes too metric-obsessed and loses sight of the human user experience.
methodologies.commonMistakes: Thinking of software as just a tool (like a hammer) rather than a medium (like a movie) that creates an emotional state.
methodologies.quote: Design is trying to imagine the future you want to live in and then take the steps to make it real... We have an obligation as product people to put that emotional energy back into people's lives.
methodologies.realWorldExample: The Apollo Program (Moon Landing) vs. standard aviation; looking at software through the lens of 'Awe and Wonder' rather than just 'Task Completion'.

levels: The Medium (Top): Emotional Resonance (Awe, Connection, Empowerment)
The Interaction (Middle): Usability & Cognitive Friction (Clear Thinking)
